Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2008 05:24PM welela52 wrote: I just finished my 4th AC round today and start Taxol in 2 weeks.  I was sure I would be able to work through the chemo - but unfortunately, I couldn't.  My first round of chemo was very rough on me - starting day 3 and lasting through day 6.  I never got nauseous or sick, just total lack of appetite and exhaustion.  I had to go on day 5 to get fluids by IV because I had dehydrated.  Since then, I've learned that I MUST eat and drink... I have to force myself to do this but it is so important.  My "bad days" have lasted longer and longer with each round.  First round was 4 days, last round was 10 days.  I'm told these last two weeks on AC could be at least 10 days possibly more due to the cumulative effect of the chemo.  So you see, working is out of the question for me.  I hated having to take medical leave, but there was no way I could work, especially when besides working 8 hours a day, I have a one hour commute each way by car.  At first I felt very guilty about taking leave.  But everyone, including my boss and co-workers, made me realize I needed to take care of ME and that the job was secondary to my health.  I don't know how I'll be on the Taxol, supposedly the effects are much less - so I may be able to return to work.  I know I'm ready - very bored  - at least on my good days - LOL!    I thought I needed the job to keep my mind busy and off the "cancer".  Those first 2 weeks were hard, not working, feeling crappy, and feeling sorry for myself.  But once everyone convinced me to take care of me, and listen to my body, it got easier.  I feel much better emotionally as the time has passed.  So Shonda, do what is best for you.  You come first before your job.  Don't put pressure on yourself that way I did.   Listen to your body and OBEY it - LOL!!!   Hopefully you will be able to work and continue pretty much normally.  Normal is good and I can't wait for it to get here again. Good Luck Zuffa.  It goes by fast, and you'll be through this before you know it.
Posts.Title: Working During Chemo zuffa kjbell

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2008 09:58PM welela52 wrote: Bluedasher, good luck with your SNB.    I'm so glad I was referred to this site.  I don't feel alone.  It's good to hear from other women who are or have experienced the same things.
Posts.Title: Arm pain welela52 Shirlann

Posts.Content: welela52 wrote: I had a lumpectomy on 9/17/08 and 2 nodes removed.  My incisions don't hurt at all. But my armpit and upper arm are VERY sensitive.  Can anyone tell me how long this will last and if there is anything I can do to alleviate the sensitivity?  It's a really creepy feeling and anything rubbing it or touching it sends a lightening bolt through my pit and arm.  Ouch!!! Welela - Never Give Up! Life is worth the fight! 9/10/08 IDC Stage 11B, Grade 3, 1/2 nodes, ER+PR+ HER-; 9/10/10 Stage IV Advanced Mets Lungs and Bone Dx 9/10/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, 1/2 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Arm pain welela52 Shirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2008 09:30PM welela52 wrote: Thanks Ladies.  Shirlann, you're right.  A heavier touch doesn't seem as bad as a light touch.  I was feelling pretty good today and was actually working in my garden, enjoying the day, relaxed, peaceful...  I must have stretched too far, or my shirt sleeve brushed my arm, whatever.... I got zapped again! LOL.  Man, that will wake you up and bring you back to reality real fast!!!!  I will tell my dr about this on Monday, which will be my first visit with the oncologist to, I assume, discuss the course of treatments to come, which my surgeon said would be rad and chemo.  Oh joy!  But, as long as I wake up every day and take a breath, I'll consider myself lucky.  Thanks again.  Best of luck and warm hugs to each of you.
Posts.Title: Arm pain welela52 Shirlann

Posts.Title: Newbie HERE welela52 Lowrider54

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2010 11:53AM - edited Sep 16, 2010 11:55AM by welela52 Ladies, thanks so much for the warm welcome.  I know I've come to the right place.  I've calmed down about the stats and realize I will not die tomorrow or next year.  I will fight this as long as I can and try whatever treatments are available.   One of you mentioned Femara - it did not do well for me at all.  They switched me to Arimidex which was easier on me, but guess not as effective - hence I'm Stage IV.   Question: is it normal (what ever normal is anymore) for the pain to come on so fast?  Ten days ago I had slight back pain, like I'd overworked at gardening or something... no big deal.  But with in the past week the pain has steadily increased until now I am really uncomfortable in my chest and back.  And of course, I can't take anything other than tylenol because I am having another biopsy tomorrow under general anesthesia.  Just curious what ya'll think of the pain thing.
Posts.Title: Newbie HERE welela52 Lowrider54

Posts.Content: welela52 wrote: Hi All!   I hope everyone is well as can be on this gorgeous (well at least here in NC) almost Autumn day. Okay... bottom line, I was just diagnosed yesterday - I have Stage IV Advanced Mets Lungs (lymph nodes and lung spots) and Bones (spine) and there are a few more suspicious areas in my chest wall.  So, that said... I still have to go for more testing.... another bone scan on Friday to correlate to the PET-CT scan I had on 9/1/10; I may have to have another lung biopsy and if I don't get into this trial the onco wants me to try, then I may have to have another port put in on Friday, as well - if I am not accepted into the trial.  I've been doing pretty good emotionally, a bit stressed today since the thoracic doc I saw this morning was so fast and out of the blue.  But I got past that.  Then, stupid stupid me... ( I have a love/hate relationshp with the internet) I started reserach this new diagnosis and frankly, it could scare the crap out of me if I was trusting in the Lord.  I saw that only about 20% of women survive past 5 years... and then there was the average survival rate of 16%....  that's could scare ya for sure and it did at first.  But then I recalled that I was trusting in the Lord for peace and strength.  I also remember Kay Yow, and though I am certainly not her nor do I pretend to have her strength, I will fight with everything my skinny (and skinnier) little body has to give. Onco wants to put me into a trial:  Faslodex and Dasatinib combo.  We'll give it a 4 months and if nothing happens or I get worse, we will switch to conventional chemo.  This trial is done by pills everyday (Dasatinib) and once monthly injections of Faslodex.  I also had my first Aredia treatment yesterday - that will also be monthly.  So everyone, I'm open to your thoughts.   (P.S. I cried today at the thoughts of my daughter having to go through this with me, and the fear that someday it could happen to her.) Welela - Never Give Up! Life is worth the fight! 9/10/08 IDC Stage 11B, Grade 3, 1/2 nodes, ER+PR+ HER-; 9/10/10 Stage IV Advanced Mets Lungs and Bone Dx 9/10/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, 1/2 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
